content.description: A Classic!   This line starts up underneath the arete. you will be horizontal and just off the ground.   Start with your hands matched on the ledge under the lip of the prow. heelhook out on a perfect heelhook ledge.   Make a long lock off to a long comfortable finger rail. get feet situated and make a left hand move to the vertical rail out far on the left side.   do a series of foot changes and a bump up the left hand rail. (I heel hook the right hand finger rail for the next move.. up to you)   toss right hand up to a sloper and then left hand to a deep jug. make you way up through easy moves to a solid and satisfyingly exposed top out.
content.protection: pads (the landing is not the poor with only one pad, but with three pads you will be more than covered)
content.location: on the arete of the maxima boulder.

content.description: Sit start on the far right side of the boulder. use a knee bar if you like, and move through two small holds. let go of the knee bar and hoist out to the long slopey crack groove. follow the groove left to the large bisecting vertical slopey crack. go with a left hand to the top of the vertical crack where it widens and becomes a slopey sidepull. deadpoint to the top. top out using the good lip and giant slab above the top out.
content.location: To the right of "Maxima" on the right face of the boulder. look for the long, obvious slopey groove that runs horizontally across the face about 9 feet up. sit start low, to the far right side of it. the sit is on the far right side of the boulder.

content.description: The "maxima" boulder is a large boulder most easily identified by the obvious arete facing the gap you walk through to get to it.   This is one of the proudest and aesthetic boulders found in the bluefield boulderfield. the lines on the maxima boulder are clean, obvious and captivating.     This boulder can be reached by walking past the speakeasy wall, turning right and walking between the "gap" or "pass" formed between the "speakeasy wall" and the "tavern wall".
